elements.title: Jersey Maritime Museum (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Jersey Maritime Museum (part of collection pictured) displays a 7.5-million-stitch tapestry depicting life under Nazi occupation that was worked on by thousands of islanders?

elements.title: 1940 NCAA Basketball Championship Game (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the 1940 NCAA Basketball Championship Game began a run of three straight NCAA Men's Basketball Tournament title games held at the Municipal Auditorium in Kansas City, Missouri?

elements.title: Alma Mater (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Alma Mater statue at Columbia University was damaged by an explosion during student protests in 1970?

elements.title: André Kisase Ngandu (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Congolese rebel leader André Kisase Ngandu criticised his Rwandan allies to such an extent that they were probably responsible for his murder?

elements.title: Euphorbia caducifolia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the desert plant Euphorbia caducifolia is commonly known as the "leafless milk hedge", while Euphorbia nivulia is the "holy milk hedge"?

elements.title: Border Violence Monitoring Network (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that in 2020, Border Violence Monitoring Network published the Black Book of Pushbacks documenting human rights violations against 12,654 migrants traveling on the Balkan route?

elements.title: May Childs Nerney (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that as secretary of the NAACP, May Childs Nerney has been credited with "laying the fundamental groundwork" for "the most powerful organization battling racial injustice"?

elements.title: St. John's Terminal (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that a club set up tennis courts on the roof of St. John's Terminal after its broker spotted it from a helicopter?
